title: Clonedel --  A Prusa Mendel Inspired RepStrap

description.text: The Clonedel RepStrap was inspired by the Prusa Mendel (see the related article). http://open3dp.me.washington.edu/2011/02/prusa-mendel-and-the-clonedels/ It came about due to necessity of students wanting to build RepRap style machines faster than we could 3D print them. It took about a week outside of class to redesign Prusa parts for mold production. Most of the parts required only minor modifications, but several parts, such as the X-Carriage assembly, required redesign. All modified parts were placed on mold pattern plates to allow for the production of silicone RTV molds. All of the STL files are now posted here and on GitHub as an Open3DP fork off of the Prusa tree. https://github.com/open3dp/PrusaMendel/downloads They are to be considered Alpha release (and we are already working on some changes). However, we am quite sure that you will be able to use them to print master forms to produce molds (because we have produced molds and we have used the molds to produce RepRaps). These mold plates represent the current best practice as provided by reprap project, prusa mendel, jnfisher, whosawhatis, rustyspoon1121, etc. Further, Metrix Create Space has already created molds sets and cast parts. Metrix Create is already making them available. http://metrixcreatespace.com/post/3587952561/clone-factory-bootstrapping {P.S. Several people have had trouble with EndStops and XMotor. I uploaded them to NetFabb Beta to fix them. I have uploaded _Fixed versions. Please let me know if these files are better.}

Print parts which are mold master, cast silicone RTV molds, and pour Clonedel parts.   Once you have made the silicone RTV molds, you should be able to cast a set of parts in about 30 minutes.
Makers may wish to have a drill press available, as all holes will need to be drilled (their locations are clearly marked with conical indents).
NOTE: the X-Clamps are not interchangeable between the X-Idler and X-Motor Mount.  One flange is 1-2 mm narrower and should go toward the rear of the machine.

If you've ever wanted to grow a square lemon, then this is for you!
Recently, I have been thinking about funny shaped fruit and have been wanting to make my own. Soon realizing that I had everything needed to do so, I gave it a try. I designed a small, two piece, box-shaped mold that is strong, snaps together, has a hole for the stem of the fruit, and printed it. I started molding lemons, as I already had a lemon tree. To use the mold, I snapped it together around the lemon, and built a support to keep it in the air. Then I was able to sit back and let the lemon do the rest. I harvested the first one three days ago, and was very excited to see that it worked!

title: NEMA17 & Bowden geared extruder for the SmartrapCore, V 0.95b

description.text: Warning : this is the OLD version of my geared extruder. You might want to get the new (and very much improved) one, at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1359717 ;)

Yet another geared extruder… ;) This one is specially designed for my SmartrapCore printer, but it can certainly be adapted for other machines. I made its body in 3 parts that you have to stack together, so it can be printed without using material support. It's really easy to assemble, though, and it allows for a convenient way to attach it to the printer's wall. It works with a Bowden and a NEMA17 step mottor. The list of extra parts and assembly tips are in the "Instructions" section. General idea is obviously derivative from the famous Greg's Wade Extruder, and gears are exactly the same, with the very effective good old Citroën chevron design. :) Update (07/30/2015) : I made minor modifications on the gears…
Update (10/12/2015) : fixed some minor issues on body & latch parts…
Update (10/13/2015) : added body-front and body-back alternate versions for a different installation method in the printer box, that could fit much better the aluminium SmartrapCore.
Update (01/25/2016) : slightly modified small and big gear, mostly by making teeth corners less sharp.
Update (01/27/2016) : modified a few things on body parts (V. 095b) to improve bearings rotation freedom & things like that…

You will need :
  • a NEMA17 step motor ;
  • a M8 hobbed bolt with the hobbed part at 25mm under the head ;
  • 2 M8 washers and 2 M8 nuts ;
  • 3 608ZZ bearings ;
  • 4 M3x25 bolts ;
  • 4 M3x10 bolts ;
  • 2 M3x50 bolts with hex head ;
  • 7 M3 nuts ;
  • 1 M3 headless screw ;
  • 2 M3 washers and springs ;
  • 2 short M3 screws for wood.
    • Assemble the 3 parts of the extruder body with 2 M3x25 bolts and their nuts, then the latch with the 2 other M3 bolts and nuts, and one of the bearings.
    Install the hobbed bolt with the big gear through the assembled body with a bearing and a washer at each side, and tighten it with the 2 M8 nuts.
    Put the little gear on the motor with an M3 nut and the headless screw (don't tighten it too much, it's fragile). Install the motor on the body with the 4 M3x10 bolts. You can then tighten the little gear at the right height (there's an opening in the body front to make it easy for you).
    Insert an M3 nut in each of the holes that are on the path of the long bolts meant to tighten the latch. Put the knobs on the 50mm hex-headed M3 bolts, then the washers and springs, and insert these to tighten the latch. Don't tighten it yet, you'll do that in the end when the filament is on its way.
    Then you can install your assembled extruder in the SmartrapCore where it suits you, with the 2 screws for the wood, and plug the motor wires in. I recommend you use it with the cables holder and filament guide I also designed (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:755862) for the SmartrapCore, they really well complete each other. :) Suggestion : print the knobs with a different color from the extruder itself, it'll be more fun. ;) VERY IMPORTANT! You must set the following variables in the Configuration.h of your Marlin firmware and recompile/upload it, otherwise your new extruder won't work, and will only make scary noises without extruding anything :
Enjoy! :)

This is a 3D printed housing for an Arduino compatible Microcontroller with integrated WiFi module, 32mm LCD Display,.USB connection, 9 axis sensor (G, turn, compass), temperature sensor and accumulator, called "radino Watch".
The "radino Watch" shield is available here: http://shop.in-circuit.de/product_info.php?cPath=22_28&products_id=36
Front and back part of the Housing can be clipped together. I printed this thing with 0.2mm layer height and 0.5mm Nozzle at a speed of 1500mm/min.

A collection of terdragons.
The terdragon was first described by Chandler Davis and Donald Knuth in 1970 in the Journal of Recreational Mathematics.  Fractal curves, similar to the terdragon, are the basis of broad band antennae.  Without them cell phones would be much larger.
Like the dragon curve (see thing:66733) the terdragon can be generated in stages.  Partially parametric openSCAD code to generate the first 7 orders of the terdragon is provided.  Lines that generate the curve are replaced by rectangular blocks whose dimensions can be chosen.
Stl files are provided for terdragon curves of degree 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7.
The openSCAD code that generated the files is terdragon_3d.scad.

Curves 2 through 5 are to the same scale and use rectangular blocks 11 mm long, 2 mm wide, and 4 mm high. They are printed in red.  Curves 6 and 7 are scaled in x and y by a factor of 1/3.  They are printed in blue.
The curves are best printed directly on the build platform.  Terdragon curves 6 and 7 need to be carefully removed but are reasonably study after separation.
Terdragon 7 contains 2187 polyhedra and takes a little under 3 hours to print.  It weights 13 grams.  See a closeup image at the upper left.

description.text: This is a small round inkwell appropriate for holding a small amount of ink, or decoratively holding a quill on a desk.

The pictured inkwell was built on a Replicator 2 using MakerWare with a 0.2 layer height, 2 shells, and 25% infill. It is pretty much water-tight as long as you have a reliable extruder (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53125 to correct the Replicator 2's extruder design flaw) and at least two shells. It uses gradual angles at the base then all 45 degree angles internally and at the top, so it should build fine with no supports. The bottom center is flat so it shouldn't need rafts either.

description.text:
Grommet /Bezel / Cable entry that holds a USB plug or socket (moulded cable type) into a panel.
Fully parameterised.
USB plug/socket on a cable is pressed into the rectangular hole in the grommet, and retained by friction and by a clamp screw.
A ring on the inside retains it.
A screw holds the ring to the flange, and bites into the USB.
Grooves allow for burrs around hole in the panel.
A Key is provided for anti-rotation, and to locate the ring to flange for easy assembly.
The small flat ended plastic screws commonly used to screw onto plastic pillars are ideal for the locking screw.

Customised the USB x,y dimensions for a tight fit on your plug, and the panel thockness and hole size.
You might find that parts of the flange on the short side of the usb plug are too thin to print or break off - don't worry about it.
Most of the USB dimmensions have no effect - they just change the rendering of the usb plug.
Printed at 0.35mm on my UP Mini.

comments.text:
I was taught never to wear gloves because what could be a small injury could end up as really serious. if you catch your finger on something sharp or moving you can pull away with a damaged finger. With gloves you wont feel anything getting caught until it is too late then you will not be able to pull away and maybe lose a hand or arm. I have seen many younsters (I am in my 60's) wear gloves to keep their hands clean when operating moving machinery! Just try this test, but be careful, dangle a bit of rag into some machinery and try and pull it out and then imagine it was your hand.
On a positive note your parting off was impressive that far away from the chuck.
I hope you and others take this comment as a genuine concern.
comments.author: 58webbing

comments.text: certainly , I use gloves because I know that at my age I have "acid" hands  . so I put them in order not to blight that I touch.
comments.author: 58webbing

comments.text: Loose fitting clothes, and gloves have no place around machine tools.   While the temptation is there to wear gloves, if a moving part of the machine were to grab that dangling string on your jacket, or your gloves, you would be severely maimed or dead.  These tools are not toys.   As a journeyman machinist for over 20 years, I appreciate young people at the trade, but safety has to be the number 1 priority.
comments.author: Rick_S

comments.text: yes, maybe they are not the appropriate clothes but I know very well the machine and the risks that I run. thank you for the criticism . I will replace my overalls.
comments.author: Rick_S

comments.text: I apologize, I didn't mean to offend.  I have seen people lose fingers, and have a friend whose father was killed by the spindle of a milling machine when it grabbed his loose fitting clothing and wrapped him around it.  I just try to protect young people starting in the trade, as I don't want to see anyone hurt like that.  Machining can be a fun and rewarding career.  Again, I apologize if I came off harsh.  Your finished parts look pretty good.

author: rdklein

title: E3D Dual/Single direct drive extruder conversion for Felix Printer

description.text:
Hi folks I'm releasing my dual or single E3D V6 Extruder as a replacement for the standard 3.0 dual extrusion. It's still in beta stage but performs in my case much better than the standard unit. The reason why i wanted to give the E3D Nozzle a try, is because I had plenty of jams with the Felix version 4 nozzle (Althougt the V3 worked perfectly for a year), and the M4 nuts from the extruder mounting couldn't be thightend anymore. They were "turning" inside the extruder-brackets (to much room, don't no the exact word in english ;). So I decided to "develope" my own conversion kit. It's been working for 50h now without any troubles. The dual extrusion setup wasn't tested yet! I've got only one E3D but the mounting looks rigid enought and leveling shouldn't be much more difficult.
Be aware, there are different files for left or right hand extruder! The hinge of the front door doesn’t need to be tightened. I’m using a M3 bolt. It would be cool, if some of you guys could give it a try, write a feedback or do a remix and post them here.. ;)
Pros:
  • posibility to print filaflex reliable (had sometimes troubels with the stock Hardware when nozzels where on the lower end of the thightening mecanism)
  • easy removal of the second extruder for a lighter carriage -> prints faster due to lighter printhead
  • Multi material, tried already PLA, ABS, Filaflex, Taulman Bridge
  • In my case much more reliablility
    • Cons:
  • You'll lose ~10mm print area on the X and Z axis
    • I'm not expecting to release an assembly gide. You should be fine with the cad files and the prictures… You'll need a few additional bolts.
    Be aware that you have to change the Thermistor settings in the Repetier Firmware to Number 8! A how to guide is on the E3D-Wiki page. All changes on the Felix Printer are your own risks ;)

author: celce

description.text:
I told my daughter to go running around the house noting things that we could create designs for.  One of the things she came up with was the typical 'over the top of the door' hanger.  After some brainstorming, we determined there was no point in just making the standard variety that you can purchase in the store.  We thought it would be better to have a modular system whereby you could assemble a specific type of hanger based on putting together very simple parts.
This thing is the modular door hanger system.  It consists of a base hanger, which is the part that goes over the door.  The base has a trapezoid shaped inverted 'V' groove which will take attachments that you can slide into place.
Along with this base, there is a very simple sample of a loop, which can be used to hang different things.
Don't be misled.  This is not just a coat hanger.  It can be anything, and you can create an infinite variety of attachments to slide into the little groove.  You can even use them in pairs to hang more complex things.
At any rate, there you go.  One more set of things for the home.  
Go create some nifty attachments.
Everything is parametric, based on the thickness of the door.

1) Print out a base
2) Print out the attachment
3) Hang the base over an open door
4) Slip the attachment into the inverted 'V' groove on the long front of the base
5) Put your thing into the attachment
6) Rejoice! When printing, you probably want to keep the base lying on its side, if your printer can deal with the support. That way you get nice long lines to help support the downward shearing force when it's on the door. For the attachment, you probably want to print such that the attachment 'shoe' is vertical on your build platform, and not flat against it. Again with the shear lines, you don't want delamination to occur at the juncture where that little rectangle offset is attached to both the shoe and the cylinder. If modularity isn't your thing, or you've settled on a base/attachment design you like, you can always do a mashup between the two and create a single solid object.

description.text:
Recently frustrated by the limited X/Y travel on my Prusa Air 2 >(https://grabcad.com/library/3d-printer-prusa-air-2-1) i wanted compact end stops. Using cheap readily available micro switches, i designed this housing with 2 types of arms > 1 standard + 1 for Z stop adjustment.
Needs 1 M3 allen head X 30mm bolt, 2 plain washers & a Nyloc nut.
Same again plus spring if you want fine adjustment on the Z endstop arm version 8 mm smaller profile than the standard ones ...works for me! Update Oct 7th 2015 > Added a housing that fits onto a 10mm dia rod ( as apposed to the original 8mm ) May add LED indicators later !

comments.text:
Thanks for your positive words.
To be honest i dont think this design will help much with your problem of filament diameter variations.
It could be adapted with a stiffer arm that may "detect" the difference in filament size but you have to remember that the internals of the micro switch itself are a mass produced mechanical device and when it comes down to reliable consistent results it may not be that good a solution.
I too have had serious issues in the past with filament quality so i understand your pain, but to design a device that could detect this, that is 3D printable may be a bit beyond the scope of the materials available to us.
comments.author: Phil_Maddox

comments.text: Great design. I've been fighting poor quality filament that has periodic bulges that won't fit into the hotend, and cause a jam. Goes with electronics box

The Clem'hand is our first shot at creating a low cost, DIY prosthetic hand. It uses body power to activate the grasp.  
All the parts are either 3D printed or available in your local hardware store. The final end of this hand is to give you a prosthesis that can easily replace the conventional ones.  
It is fairly easy to make and available to anyone.  
It also includes a blocking mechanism to hold objects without maintaining the grasp with your shoulder. Be careful though, the system is functional but does not quite fit with every objects.  
The design is entirely based on a 3D scan of a real hand, hence the good-looking global shape of the hand.  
You can also rotate the thumb between 2 positions, granting you with 2 types of grasping. It will allow you to pick up small objects such as your wallet, a book, etc. or carrying bigger objects or even taking with you your water bottle or your glass.
All the instructions are available in the PDF documents (one in French, and one in English)

description.text: The idea behind this instrument is that you print the bracket, and mount onto the X carriage on a Mendel.  The rod is then dropped into the bracket and allowed to drag across the surface of the build platform.  As the rod is dragged across the surface, it will extend and retract depending on the current height per location on the platform.  This is a simple and cheap alternative to a Height Gauge.  The resolution is limited as compared to an authentic height gauge, but i suspect is a worthy alternative.

Print 'Level_Bracket.stl' For the measuring rod:
Cut a length of smooth rod approximately 100mm long. The material doesnt matter. As long as it is smooth and 8mm radius. Round out one end as smooth as possible to allow for minimal friction as it drags on the platform surface. This is the hard part. Use a laser cutter/etcher and etch precise lines into the rod to be used as your measuring units. You may use the attached 'Level_Units.eps' as a template. These marks will be used to determine the delta in Z as you travel between quadrants of your platform. The lines in the provided files are separated in millimeters. When i get a chance to make this ill experiment with finer lines.

title: Chickadee Glider
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is one of my older planes - it flies pretty good, but there's a lot of better ones available to print now! Now we have a full sized glider that can print on your 100mm bed! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:300168 We also have a full collection of 100mm printable gliders, great tips for printing these little flyers on our blog, and more at at http://threedsy.com! Launcher and tools: For instructions look at my glider instruction thing:1465700. For tips on printing glider wings, drop by my blog at threedsy.com and if you like our models, keep us designing for you instead of flipping burgers by purchasing one of our premium designs from the site! If you want to learn how to design amazing, highly functional designs for 3d printing, design and print useful repair parts, and generally print useful stuff faster, more reliably, and with less problems check out my books, Functional design for 3D printing and the Zombie Apocalypse Guide to 3D Printing on Amazon! If you like my gliders, check out my other models here on thingiverse and more models and books I wrote on 3D Design and 3D Printing here at threedsy.com Finally, for folks with a smaller print bed, or just a love for tiny stuff.. Very long flights are possible with this tiny glider when launched with a rubber band or off of something high.
With practice, it is hand launchable by holding between the wing and empanage.

Edits:   
Now, U2A and U2B Version STL's, longer wings (a is long, b is very long)  
....and a U2C version, slightly lighter, hollow fuselage and easier to build correctly. (reworked vertical stabilizer) . This one may not slice correctly if you have a nozzle width other than .35.  
These 'U2' versions are more challenging to print and tune, but offer the possibility of better performance and slow flight capabilities. These use more than 100mm of build space.  
Updated , cleaner models and STL Files, a double print STL for larger printers,  and a new .STL with.6mm wing spar heights for anyone having trouble getting the layers to work out. This new .6mm spar model has not been tested, but I do not expect any problems. If you print it, please comment on the results... thanks!  
Protips:   
Your printer will need to be capable of printing smooth 1 and 2 layer .15mm prints. Adjust your first layer settings to achieve solid layers with no surface debris or curling.  
Some cleaning of print artifacts and fit checking is a good idea prior to getting out the glue...  
Layer height matters, as does fill ratio. Increasing the fill ratio for the fuselage will shift the CG forward, which may be desirable depending on your results.   
I am using .15532 layer height and a bottom layer height close to 50% (.08ish) - you will want to be as close to this as possible, or calculate a layer height that gives 4 layers at .50mm on your setup.   
The important thing is that the web of the flying surfaces should be two layers, and the spars and wingtip reinforcements should be 4 (3 Layers should work too, but the CG might end up a bit aft due to the thicker first layer. If you can't get it to fly stable, try a tiny bit of weight forward. On a tiny flying model like this, the details really count).  
More layers should also be ok as long as they are very thin so that  weight does not increase too dramatically....I am using 300mm of 3mm filament  
My nozzle is .35mm, but a .5 should work fine. If your nozzle is smaller than .33, adjust the perimeters accordingly.  
The wing must be very flat. Use care when removing the wing and tail sections from the bed. Peel up from the tips toward the fuselage with a thin blade or spatula, lifting only as much as needed to break free, being careful not to disturb the spanwise symmetry. If the wings are not perfectly symetrical when viewed from the front of the aircraft, adjustments will be required for proper performance.  
Glue the tail and canopy / hook into place with a tiny drop of superglue.

Known working instructions:  
Print the chickadee using ABS, .155 layer height with a .5 first layer height (or close). Use 2 perimeters, and 2 solid layers, 30%  rectalinear fill (you can increase the fill ratio to move the CG forward if desired) . Use a fill orientation of 0 degrees to the axis of the fuselage (natural axis of the print). 45 degrees works also, but causes uneven flexing of the wings under load, resulting in a strong turning tendency at high launch speeds.  
Print the launcher with 3 perimeters (2 for .5 nozzle), 2 solid layers, and .35 line fill. Two perimeters are not enough, and will break. Scale the part to your preference - it is not layer critical.  
Flight tips:  
Fly with eye protection if using the rubber band launcher! The plane is tiny, hard to see, and may return to the point of launch at high speed. (yes, I did hit myself in the eye flying this plane)  
Carefully bow the wings upward to give a slight rounded dihedral.   
Carefully bend in a tiny bit of up elevator so the plane does not dive towards the ground. Adjust elevon surfaces further as needed until the plane flies straight and level.  
Put on your safety glasses, a nice stretchy 2mm cross section  (12-18" extended) rubber band on the launcher, and fly!  
A small amount of weight (1/2 of a 3mm washer, etc) can be glued to the fuselage aft of the hook for more stability or longer flights.   
Except in extreme cases, do not bend ailerons in the wing. Use the elevators as elevons instead. Using the rudder will cause side-slip drag, and will result in shorter flights. If the model seems to be skidding, use the rudder to align the fuselage to the direction of flight, then elevon tweaking to get straight and level or any other desired flight profile.  
A neat trick is to adjust the pane for straight looping flight, then launch at about a 30 degree roll angle, slightly upward. Keep adjusting launch and control profiles until the plane circles around so that you can catch it.  
Other materials and layer heights may work as well, please post your results!

comments.text: nice model, but I have tried 2 verions of slic3r and it will give me 2 layers for the wings but only 3 not 4 on the wing tip reinforcements?  i took a look in netfab and it appears the wing tips are only .5mm? so would need a .125 layer?
comments.author: stu121

comments.text: I think I know what the issue is - I have a fractional first layer ratio set, .6 ish, I think (slicer is busy right now) . 3 Layers should work too, but the cg might end up a bit aft due to the thicker first layer. author: killmsry

description.text:
This thing is a sticker roll that fits Dymo LabelWriter 450 / 450 Turbo.  
It consists of two parts. The roll and a side piece that attaches to the roll axis. I've also added a .stl file that contains both.  
I created this thing using SkethUp and by measuring the original part and making a simplified replica that fits and does the job. This published version is the third version and good enough to put out there I think.   
At my work I need to print different sized stickers every now and then and I find it annoying to completely remove the roll, unload the sticker roll, reload the roll with different size stickers and then insert the roll back inside the Dymo. I decided that I could print rolls for all the sticker rolls and when I need to change sizes, I can just remove the whole package (roll + stickers) and insert another sticker roll, already attached to a roll.

I was using Ultimaker 2 and the heated buildplate tends to make the first few layers "expand" or spread out a little. For me this was desired because it makes the fit between parts more snug. I also needed to hone the hole a little bit to make it fit at all, but it is now very tight.   
I would suggest printing support structure for the roll it self and perhaps printing the side piece directly on build plate.

description.text: Scanned face

title: Robot Sensor Horn for Sharp IR Sensors

description.text:
I designed this sensor horn in order to implement a very simple mapping algorithm on a mobile robot. This allows you to see all 360 with two sensors and a standard micro servo(I got mine in a ten pack off ebay for not much at all) in one 180 degree rotation.
I had this made out of wood originally. It wasn't very good. Now that I have a ToM, I'm excited to improve upon my design.
I'll mark this complete when I get it to print without having to use my dremel drill press. I also need to replace the belt on my ABP, I rigged it with a layer of kapton tape for this print, but it still ended up a little warped and weird. Then there's a mountain of things I could do to tune my printer as well. :D
As for the algorithm, I got around not having an encoder by timing the amount it took for the horn to make one full revolution*. (the el cheapo servos only move at one speed) I take the total time it rotates and divide that by the amount of samples it took during that time for one sensor. I then multiply that number by 180 degrees to get the increment of the theta component for each sample. The end result is a set of polar coordinates for 360degrees around the robot.
You could also just take a measurement every (rotation time)/180 for each sensor, which gives you a smaller array, but it's a bit easier to work with. I didn't really see too much difference.
*the robot still moves the sensor past this time to make sure it reaches the maximum of its travel. The robot just waited a set delay when moving one direction before taking measurements (since only one side traveled too far on the little servos I have). Its a bit inaccurate, but it worked well enough to hug walls, avoid chair legs, and go through doors.

print
drill out holes if necessary
screw onto servo horn
bolt sensors on with m3 bolts
robot Also, if anyone sees my other tank tread lying around let me know. My robot is a whole lot less exciting when it can only turn. :(

title: Turnout for Garden Railway Track System 32mm

description.text:
Turnout for 32mm gauge tracks (SM32) common used in Garden railways (16mm and 7/8th scale).
The turnout radius are 762mm and a steeper radius curved track is included , i will release the curved track as a standalone Track in the future.
Updated 20150601: Now with "dual" STL files for dual printers.

It should be easy to print.
decide if you want to print left or right turnout and print one of each L or R part files . Part 4 are the same for both L or R.
All STL files has been tested in Netfabb.
I have printed my turnouts with PLA at 0.3mm layer height and 50% infill .
Part 3 STL:s are printed with 0.2mm layer height.

title: Water Wheel for inside a tube

description.text: Designed to help a student with a project.  The wheel is designed to fit inside a water pipe.  I included a PDF of the dimensions from the CAD model.  It is designed for a 4" pipe - but is untested as of now.  The CAD model includes some reinforcement modifications in the vanes.  I've uploaded a "reinforced" model file as well.

Printed in PLA with a .4mm nozzle @ .3mm layers, 70% infill, with support material generated for over 45 degree angles.  Also printed a brim of 2mm to ensure it adhered to the print bed.  
We have not tested how it functions in a water pipe.  At this point it is a concept - but it turned out cool so we shared it.

Allows extended space underneath the Ultimaker printer for its power supply brick and an extra heated bed power supply. Uses a four-way locking hinge system allows opening from any side without extra hardware.  
This system with three pieces per foot and allows simple manual locking of the hinges and opening/swinging from any four sides of the printer.  
All parts are designed to print without support.  
Some filing may be necessary on printed plastic drippings so that the hinge and lever rotate nicely.  
The lever snaps into 45 degree positions by slightly bending a plastic octagon shape.  
Tape and cardboard may be necessary to make the wood fit tightly into the hinge and woodbracket pieces.  
The wooden baseplate is the same dimensions as the outer dimensions of the  3D printer.

title: Autohoming Unicorn G-Code Extension for Inkscape

description.text: This is a very minor hack to Schmarty's excellent Unicorn G-Code Extension for Inkscape. Now when you create some GCode with Inkscape, it can autohome the XY platform before registering and printing. It incorporates the "start.txt" and "end.txt" from my autohoming code. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6741 The image is from Mifga's carrier pigeon, just because it's interesting. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6294

• Find your Inkscape's extension folder (Mine was here:
    InkscapePortable\App\Inkscape\share\extensions\unicorn)
  • Rename or move your existing "context.py"
  • Copy the file below, "context.py" into your unicorn extension folder
  • Yay!

comments.text: It doesn't really match any mouthpiece that I use very closely. I would say that it probably has a larger rim than a 7C, just based on feel. I don't really know how I would go about making a 7C replica unless I had a profile of the cup and backbore.
comments.author: MusicMan10

comments.text: and how do you design these
comments.author: MusicMan10

comments.text: I used a digital caliper to take measurements of the mouthpiece, and then used Autodesk Inventor to create the model. Getting the right shape for the cup seems to be more of an art than a science, so I had to mess with it for awhile.

comments.text: They seem to take about 2.5 hours on high resolution on the Makerbot Replicator 2. These ones definitely fit in an actual trumpet. I've used them in my Schilke S22 and even a little in a Getzen Piccolo trumpet. They definitely have more of a jazzy sound, kind of smoky, think jazz tenor sax. I've made 3 of them so far and given two of them away. I'll post pictures of my actual mouthpieces sometime soon.

description.text:
This egg painter holds an egg and let you easily paint an egg.
You can turn the egg by turning the knobs and paint a beautiful pattern.
Happy Easter !

Print with 20% infill. I printed the rods in a different color.
You need two springs for the rods.
Put the rods in the holder, add the springs and glue/screw the caps to the rods.
Done. Happy Easter Egg Painting Tip: Try out GCodeSimulator to check your print upfront
Homepage: http://gcodesim.dietzm.de
On Thingiverse: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:44286
Control your printer from an Android device
Homepage: http://gcodeprintr.dietzm.de/#GCodePrintr

description.text: It's a charm for my girlfriend
3d bunny cookie

*Print cutter  
*choose a cookie dough that won’t rise or spread much  
*Role dough out to a thickness of 1/8 in or 3mm. I use shish kabob skewers as guides  
*bake on silicone bake sheets, or though I haven’t tried it my grandma suggested parchment paper.  
*Bake if the slot gets deformed in moving to cookie sheet or backing just widen it with a knife while its still warm.  
*wait till cool then slide cookies together

author: redbozz

description.text: simply elastic fastener to hang your cables, filament or other

Just print
No support require
I've designed a case for my cubieboard. Top case is for Cubieboard, bottom one for SATA HDD (you can use USB->SATA adapter from A-Data CH93 or SATA connector from Cubieboard).

Bottom parts needs to be printed with support (45* recommended).
HDD Case can be used separately. You should glue some soft material inside for HDD safety. It is designed to fit AData CH-93 electronics (for USB) or SATA cable.
 
This two cases can be placed on top of each other and connected with long screws or parts of 3mm filament.
 
Power button is part of 3mm filament, melted on one side.

• borders thickness reduced to 4mm.
  • bottom of case reduced by 2mm (in version V1 I couldn't connect external ports for GPIO)
  • printing time reduced to 60% by modifications above :)
  • bigger holes for HDMI, USB-OTG, audio and IR
  • HDD case adjusted to Cubieboard case.

description.text: A simple case for the Microcode DSP Morse reader.

Its a simple box, one of the first things I made with ViaCAD, the box only has holes for the lids, LCD, buttons, and led, you will need to make holes to mount the Microcode DSP to the lid, and any holes for power, switches or input, I just used a drill.  
The box size is 113mm x 58mm x 56mm on the outside, the walls are 3mm thick, the lid screw holes are 3mm, and the box screw holes are 2.5mm, the Microcode DSP fits into the case, but it is a tight fit.  
I used a LM2596 DC-DC converter for the 12v DC power, I hot glued it in place.  
I had to make spacers that fit between the Microcode DSP and the top lid, the spacers are 7mm long, 6mm wide, and have a 3mm hole, I used M2.5 x 25mm screws to fasten the Microcode DSP to the lid.   
This is one of the first 3D models I made, it's not perfect, but I was able to use it, so I decided to share, the STP and STL files were made with ViaCad v8.

title: Clamps for Mendel inspired x and y carriage lowrider

description.text:
After the trouble with the magnets and the old carriage I thought this might need the clamps as well. With the help of the added bolts the platform slides down firmly to its place and gets lock down with the lever on the right hand side.
When closed the lever is equal with the platform edge and is nicely hidden out of the way.

Two ways of making this work (after printing the left and right stls).
  • Drill the holes to the existing carriage with the help of my awesome paint instructions.. or
  • Print the original carriage stl's that got modified.
    • Then insert one 3x10 bolt to the 07part with nut and one original m3 bolt (that came with the bot) to the 08part.
    Attach the clamps to the platform and for the lever part I suggest you use either thread locker or a nyloc nut. Test operation. The platform should slide to its place and the lever should turn to its place with ease and be level with platform edge.
